text: the euphoria that greeted Maharis
swearing-in after his fourth attempt at
the presidency can still be felt in the
country today defeating Boko Haram was a
major campaign promise
while all territory held by the group
has been regained the number of people
who have died in attacks has risen
dramatically over 1,000 people have been
killed since mihari took power most by
suicide bombers what it entails now is
the cooperation from everybody so the
best source of information could emanate
from such people next on his agenda was
the promise to tackle Nigeria's endemic
corruption called into question has been
the country's oil industry and other
public institutions
Bihari has promised that those
responsible could be in court in a
matter of weeks by fighting corruption
in a place like Nigeria is an uphill
task nobody keeps illegitimate resources
or assets in their names most times they
move them out of the immediate
environment so the processes of tracking
these assets and these funds that are
solely they are soaked impossible
perhaps the biggest problem for most
Nigerians today is the state of the
economy many citizens are worried about
meeting their basic daily needs Nigeria
is Africa's largest producer of oil
accounting for about 70% of its revenue
but with falling global prices of oil
the country has seen its currency lose
value Nigeria based is 2015 budget on
oil at 53 dollars a barrel a price that
has dropped and keeps fluctuating this
means the government simply won't have
the money
needs to operate so how dangerous is it
for Nigeria to rely so heavily on its
oil sector where there are challenges
there are also opportunities and this is
an opportunity for the Nigerian economy
to diversify away from dependence on
petroleum so while his victory was met
with great joy and his presidency held
to high expectations President Muhammadu
Buhari has his work cut out for him as
he goes into the landmark 100 days in
office
Abdullah era Abubakar BBC News Abuja
Nigeria
